text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
We're living in a time where there are
a lot of interesting technological advances happening.
You can just think about things like the rise of AI
and also the proliferation of platforms.
You can think about Amazon and eBay.
You can also think about Airbnb and Uber.

And as we think about their impact
on society,

it's important
to think about the financial implications,

but it's also important
to think about the social implications
of the decisions they're making.
To some degree better information is good,

but then the question is,
who controls that better information?
What do you do with it?

So it's wrong to ask the question,
what will AI do to labor?

The right question is 
what we will decide to do with
AI and how this will impact inequality.

These online platforms
have now taken a big part of the economy,
so you get your information from Google,

you interact with your friends
on Twitter and Facebook.

You order through Amazon
and you book a cab through Uber.

So they now
have a big part of our society,

which means they have a lot of power
and I will say even responsibility.

My recent research focuses on tradeoffs
between accuracy.

But at the same time,
there's a lot of interest

and concern
about fairness of these algorithms.
Having diverse perspectives actually improves

how science is done in the economics
profession and other fields
And its cross-disciplinary in nature

because we need to hear from sociologists,
psychologists, philosophers, ethicists.

So there are large numbers of people
studying bias in AI.

There are institutes that are cropping up
whose main job it is to focus on these.

I think we will be okay,
but only if we don't let

corporate interests drive
how this work unfolds.

I think today
we have a more open conversation

about how we can use new technologies
for workers.

Labor unions have become more awake
to the issues of digital technologies

and AI, and I think there's a broader
openness in the U.S. society that was absent

just four years ago about regulation
and reducing the power of big tech.

I think all of those are useful
developments.
I believe AI is good for society,

at the end of the day, even though I 
research about algorithmic bias and fairness.

It has so much promise,
but it also has some perils.

We just need to manage the perils
as we develop the promises.
